entry.title: VAT condition‚Äìbased billing document extraction report
entry.content:
Dear community,

We want to retrieve billing documents for one or multiple company codes / sales organization, based on the VAT code or VAT condition number. From a technical perspective, we need to read all billing documents determined by the selection screen, get the condition record numbers, and check which condition records or VAT codes fulfil the requirements. Based on the records found in the table PRCD_ELEMENTS, we keep only the relevant billing documents and delete all records which do not fit.

Can you please advise if SAP have something available to cover this?

entry.title: Re: Analysis file generated out of RC_COLLECT_ANALYSIS_DA...
entry.content: In the SAP Note, 3059197 - SAP Readiness Check for SAP S/4HANA upgrades, under Frequently Asked Questions? section, Question no # 10 is saying that we could copen the files in Edge and Firefox browser. 10. How exactly can I see the data before uploading it to SAP? SAP offers XSL (Extensible Stylesheet Language) files for the contents of the ZIP file that is generated from the RC_COLLECT_ANALYSIS_DATA report. These XSL files enable the XML files to be displayed in a ‚Äúhuman-readable‚Äù format in Microsoft Edge and Mozilla Firefox.

entry.title: Re: Datasphere: Difference between Role Privilege "Connec...
entry.content:
Hi, 

it may be a bit confusing here. 

Data Warehouse Connection privilege is required when you would like to establish connections in DSP. 

Connection privilege is needed if you want to create new Cloud Connector. Normally you do need only once during the setup of the DSP tenant. 

Martin

entry.title: Re: Depreciation Key for Immediate Expense
entry.content:
HI @kiel01 ,

 

StepT-CodeObjectExample IDKey Fields / SettingsPurpose / Description
1AFAMADepreciation KeyZIMM- Base Method: Z100 - Multilevel Method: ZEXP - Period Control: 01 - Cutoff Method: Blank - Useful Life Dependency: NoCreates custom depreciation key for full expense in acquisition month
2AFAMDBase MethodZ100- Depreciation Type: Ordinary - Depreciation to the Day: No - Start of Depreciation: Acquisition Period - Period Control (Acquisition): 01 - Period Control (Retirement): 00Defines basic depreciation logic to trigger same-period posting
3AFAMSMultilevel MethodZEXP- Level: 1 - Depreciation Type: Ordinary - Base Value: Acquisition Value - Percentage Rate: 100% - Valid From/To: Period 1 ‚Äì Period 1 - Period Control: 01Ensures full 100% depreciation charged immediately in acquisition period
4AFAMPPeriod Control Method1- Acquisition: 01 (Full in acquisition period) - Retirement: 00 (No depreciation) - Transfer: 00 - Write-Up: 00Determines timing of depreciation recognition
5OAYZAsset Class AssignmentAs per business requirement- Assign Depreciation Key: ZIMM - Company Code: Relevant entityApplies immediate-expense key to specific asset class
6AS01 / AS91Asset MasterAsset with ZIMM key- Depreciation Key: ZIMM - Asset Class: Linked to immediate expenseUsed for acquisition test and depreciation simulation
7AFABDepreciation RunN/ARun for acquisition periodVerifies that 100% of acquisition value is expensed in same month

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Re: In EPPM, what's the accrual revenue calculation metho...
entry.content: Event based Rev Rec still uses the Results Analysis configuration.  Look at the RA configuration where G/L accounts are assigned to a Line ID (LID), this is where the values are aggregated and used for postings.  So it's not calculated on a G/L line item level, it's calculated on the LID level.

entry.title: Re: Automated mass updates for Asset
entry.content:
HI @aalmayyahi ,

Here is proposed solution.

 

AspectDetails
ObjectiveMass update of ~500 existing asset master records to modify fields under the Time-Dependent tab ‚Äî Personal Number, Department, Division.
Current LimitationAS02 allows edits but only one asset at a time.
Recommended SolutionUse BAPI BAPI_FIXEDASSET_CHANGE with structure BAPIFIXASSET_TIMEDATA for automated upload.
Alternative Methods1Ô∏è‚É£ LSMW (Object 0105 ‚Äì Asset Master: Change)2Ô∏è‚É£ MASS transaction (limited field access)3Ô∏è‚É£ Custom ABAP BDC for AS02 (legacy option).
Key Fields to UpdatePERSON_NO (Personal Number), DEPARTMENT (Department), DIVISION (Division).
BAPI ParametersStructure: BAPIFIXASSET_TIMEDATAFields: VALID_FROM, PERSON_NO, DEPARTMENT, DIVISION.
Input File (Excel/CSV)Columns: CompanyCode, AssetNumber, SubNumber, ValidFromDate, PersonalNumber, Department, Division.
Execution Flow1. Extract asset list (ANLA/ANLZ).2. Prepare Excel with new values.3. Run ABAP/LSMW calling BAPI.4. Commit in batches of 50‚Äì100.5. Validate via AS03/AW01N.6. Capture BAPIRET2 messages.
Sample Function CallsBAPI_FIXEDASSET_CHANGE ‚Üí Update data.BAPI_TRANSACTION_COMMIT ‚Üí Save permanently.
Main Tables AffectedANLZ ‚Äì Asset Time-Dependent Data.
Validation / ReportsAS03, AW01N, SE16N (ANLZ) for confirmation.
Error LoggingCapture messages from BAPIRET2 table for each asset.
Authorization CheckRequires change access (AIST, AICH, AS02).
Performance TipUse commit after 50‚Äì100 assets; avoid single commit per record.
Best PracticeTest in QA with 2‚Äì3 sample assets ‚Üí Validate results ‚Üí Transport to production.
Expected OutcomeAll 500 assets updated with new values in the same ‚ÄúValid From‚Äù period; full change logs maintained automatically.
Feasibility‚úÖ Fully supported by SAP; safe for productive use.
Effort Levelüîπ Medium ‚Äì requires ABAP or LSMW setup.
Recommended ApproachBAPI_FIXEDASSET_CHANGE ‚Äì Reliable, auditable, efficient method for mass updates.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Re: Empowering Business Users with Personalized News in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 Releas
entry.content: Hi Joceyln ,  The minimum SAPUI5 version for the Manage News app is not a single fixed number, as it depends on the specific release and feature packages. The Manage News app will be delivered to private cloud customers in the SAP S/4HANA 2025 release. The current release for SAP S/4HANA 2025 is based on the latest UI5 versions available for that release, and it's recommended to use the most current stable version for optimal performance.  Thanks, Caroline.

entry.title: C4C 2508.03.0001 Spam Filtering
entry.content:
Our customer facing email address are experiencing an increased number of spam emails being received into C4C, thus creating invalid tickets in our system.

We use Microsoft Exchange and typically do not allow external forwarding but have enabled external forwarding to our C4C system. These are then setup as B2B email channels in C4C.

We understand that this method routes emails directly from the shared inbox to C4C without spam filtering first processing.

Questions:

We are very likely not the only company that utilizes Microsoft Exchange for our spam filtering, so what is the recommended approach for spam filtering and C4C email channels?

Can C4C pull messages via Microsoft Graph API or direct mailbox access?

Is whitelisting and blocking the only spam filtering that C4C is capable of?

Solution Testing:

We are testing using a transport rule to route emails based on the spam confidence level that is in the email header.

Is this an approach that customers typically use?

entry.title: Re: Why SAP Crystal Reports Viewer doesn't support Window...
entry.content:
First thing I suggest is to upgrade to SP 38, the Viewer in SP 37 has a lot of issues.

You didn't answer directly so asking again, is this a WEB app?

If it is then possibly you need to use Sessions and PostBack functions, see this KBA:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/1985571

This keeps IIS using the same Report in session and any communications within the PostBack method.

The issue is CR can't directly communicate with IIS to pass the Preview back to the client. CR can't generate the page until the report is processed.

If it's a desktop app then I tested it using the latest Snagit and all I see is the Snagit's print preview.

And yes, using P2P is CR Basic Printer function, to have more control you should use POC API.

See my sample printer app on this page:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SUPPORT_CONTENT/crystalreports/3354091173.html?locale=en-US

Printing Crystal Reports in .NET

Select the printer, Set  Printerand then using POC button to print, see if that works for you.

entry.title: Re: Configuration: Group payment batches by bank in BCM,...
entry.content:
Hello,

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, there is an automatic grouping of payment batches according to house banks and house bank accounts happening as part of the standard functionality in Bank Communication Management and Bank Account Management. The configuration you are showing is implicitly used by the system. However, these are best practices that are delivered out-of-the-box and to my knowledge they are not configurable via SSCUI.

By using SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition for advanced payment management, you will have additional options to activate grouping via app "Manage Payment Agreements":

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/b8e68a90bfff4ff0906d5db5342bdece/0eacbdbfb6aa41b6b2858272eea7f44e.html?version=LATEST&locale=en-US

Also, I would like to make you aware of the following item in the roadmap explorer that is concerned with a flexibilization of the approval process in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition:

https://roadmaps.sap.com/board?q=approval&range=FIRST-LAST#Q4%202025;INNO=000D3AAADBCE1FE0A396B5BF19EF11D0

I hope this information is helpful.

Best regards,

Jens

entry.title: SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud 2511 Release Briefing
entry.content:
Hi All,

Please see the presentation - SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud 2511 Release Briefing.

We have some key innovations and some important deprecation messages to be shared as part of SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud 2511 Release.

Platform & Integration:

Transition Tools:

  • Data Transfer Tool (DTT) | Decouple Business Configuration (BC) load and data load - To avoid implicit transfer of BC from V1 to V2 with business object data transfer
  • Readiness Check Tool (RCT) | Show additional artifacts related to Attachments and Activities - The Attachments tab lists the number of attachments of business objects in your SAP Cloud for Customer system. The Activities in Tickets tab lists Activity Type and Number of Activities associated with Tickets.
  • Data Transfer Tool (DTT) | Pre-requisite checks and Error Details - Additional Checks are done before transferring data from V1 to V2, like scoped services check in V2, pre-requisites like case type mapping. Error details lists the type of error that the particular business object encounters while transferring data.

UI Framework:

  • UI Framework | User Consent for accessing external sites for Maps - This new feature will show a one-time user consent popup before C4C application first access to external sites like Google to check if the map feature, which saves the user's location information, is available or not, giving the user an opportunity to agree or deny, restricting the C4C system to access external sites without consent from the user.
  • UI Framework | Option in My Settings to allow/deny access to external sites - Later, the user can modify the choice of their consent under My Settings ‚Äì External Services ‚Äì Allow External Maps.

Integration with SAP Jam - Deprecation Message:

As per SAP‚Äôs strategic decision to exit the standalone collaboration area and focus on the Digital Workplace Experience market with products, such as SAP Build Work Zone, which SAP announced and communicated to you in 2021, SAP Jam Collaboration will be sunset and no longer accessible as of 1st January 2027. This applies to all SAP Jam Collaboration editions: Basic, Advanced, Advanced Plus, and Enterprise. For more information, refer to the SAP Jam Collaboration Sunset Information published on SAP Community.

As a result, you will no longer be able to use or access SAP Jam as part of your Sales or Service Cloud Professional/Enterprise bundle SKU after 31st of December 2026. However, if you are using SAP Jam as part of your Sales and Service V1 processes, and wish to continue using collaboration capabilities beyond the end of 2026, we request that you reach out to your account representative, raise a support ticket, or, if neither of these options is available to you, reach out to customer support.

Feeds:

Feeds | Integration with SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition - As an Administrator, you have an option to use SAP Jam (until 31st December 2026) or SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition for collaboration via Feeds.

Customer Support:

Customer Support | Built-In Support Integration with SAP for Me: 

With the upcoming 2511 release, SAP Sales & Service Cloud (V1) receives a major upgrade to its built-in support experience. You will continue to report issues directly from your tenant, now through the next-generation Built-In Support, seamlessly integrated with SAP for Me.  For more information, please refer to this blog - Smarter Built-In Support in C4C: A Unified and Upgraded Experience

SAP Sales Cloud:

Opportunity Management - Complete mandatory Surveys before closing an Opportunity

SAP Service Cloud:

C4C-FSM Integration ‚Äì Change current SAP Field Service Management (FSM) domains to new FSM domain

Deprecation Message:
It is mandatory that you change your current domain in your FSM integration settings from *.coresystems.net and.*.coresuite.com to the new domain *.cloud.sap. Current and new domains are supported in parallel only until March 1, 2026. Your existing browser bookmarks and FSM APIs will work without disruption until the current FSM domains are decommissioned on March 1, 2026.

SAP is unifying all Field Service Management domains to improve UI integrations between products. Solutions hosted on different data centers are treated like third-party applications. Isolation and privacy features implemented by modern browsers isolate SAP products if they are hosted with different domains. These isolation features are locked down further with every browser release. Integration scenarios that use iFrames or cross-origin requests‚Äìfor example with authentication‚Äìwill break once 3rd-party cookies are disabled. For more information, see the help topic  - Common Superdomain for SaaS Applications in SAP Field Service Management documentation.

Next steps:

  1. Go to Administrator > Service and Social > Field Service Management > Configure FSM Integration. Change the domain in the FSM system URLs from *.coresystems.net and *.coresuite.com to the new domain *.cloud.sap.
  2. Update the URLs in your integration flows (iFlows) used for FSM to C4C integration to reflect the new domain.

Thanks,

SAP Sales Cloud & SAP Service Cloud Product Management Team

entry.title: Choosing the Right Connector: Identity Authentication or Identity Directory?
entry.content:
When two connectors look alike, it's easy to mistake one for the other. This is exactly the case with Identity Authentication (version 2) and Local Identity Directory in SAP Cloud Identity Services ‚Äì Identity Provisioning. Although they may appear similar at first, each is designed for a specific purpose.

So why are they often mixed up, and where does the confusion come from?

 

Who‚Äôs Who?

Both connectors are named after two SAP Cloud Identity Services (SCI): Identity Authentication, which handles user authentication and Single Sign-On in the cloud, and Identity Directory, which serves as the user store in SCI.

They were developed several years apart, with Identity Authentication introduced first. This original connector is now referred to as version 1. Its SCIM REST API is deprecated and will be decommissioned on November 30, 2026.

The Identity Directory SCIM API was introduced as the successor to the old one. Both connectors, which read and write users and groups in the SCI user store, now call the same Identity Directory SCIM API. For more information, see Identity Directory API. Additionally, they both support the provisioning of application-specific groups.

However, there is an important distinction:

  • With Identity Authentication, you can read from and write to the Identity Directory of another SCI tenant. While it is also possible to configure Identity Authentication for read and write operations within the same SCI tenant, this requires additional effort and does not take advantage of the out-of-the-box configuration. For more information, see Identity Authentication (source) and Identity Authentication (target).
  • With the Local Identity Directory, you access the Identity Directory of your own SCI tenant for reading and writing operations. For more information, see Identity Directory (source) and Identity Directory (target).

 

 

Similarities and Differences

The table below outlines the key similarities and differences between Identity Authentication version 2 and Local Identity Directory:

 

Identity Provisioning ConnectorCommunication and authentication setupCentral store-based provisioningIPS tenants running on Neo environment 
Identity Authentication v 2YesNoYes
 Communication and authentication must be setup as you are connecting to the identity directory of another SCI tenant.Central store-based provisioning (also called  event-based provisioning) is not supported for IAS version 2 source system.You can use Identity Authentication version 2 connector if your Identity Provisioning tenant is running on Neo environment.
 See List of Properties See Central Store-Based ProvisioningSee Identity Authentication
Local Identity DirectoryNoYesNo
 Communication and authentication is not required as you are connecting to the identity directory of your currently used SCI tenant.Central store-based provisioning (also called event-based provisioning) is only supported for Local Identity Directory source system.You can't use the Local Identity Directory connector if your Identity Provisioning tenant is running on the Neo environment.
  See Central Store-Based Provisioning 

 

Choosing the right connector depends on your scenario and your understanding of how each one works. In identity management, as in most fields, knowing the difference makes all the difference.

entry.title: For Business/System Analysts who work with ERP integrations.
entry.content:
When designing ERP integrations (for AR/AP document flows), Business/System Analysts often face a range of ‚Äúgotcha‚Äù questions ‚Äî technical, architectural, and sometimes unexpected.
Here are some of the real-world questions I ask clients during the API and ERP connector discovery phase:

  1. What‚Äôs the minimum required ERP version to support all AR/AP endpoints?
  2. Could upgrading the ERP version change the API behavior (fields, formats)?
  3. Are there any heavy or slow API methods under load? Recommended workarounds?
  4. Does the ERP provider charge for API calls, or is usage unlimited?
  5. Can we get a list of possible API error codes?
  6. Any record count limits per request? (e.g., max 1000 records in GET)
  7. What type of authentication is used ‚Äî Basic Auth, OAuth2, or token-based?
  8. What‚Äôs the average response time of the API?
  9. Are there any debug/logging tools if something goes wrong with the call?
  10. Any breaking changes in recent patches that could affect us?
  11. Does the API support batch insert/update or only record-by-record?
  12. In what format are dates returned? Full datetime or date-only?
  13. How are balances returned (positive/negative for credit memos)?
  14. Can documents be posted without updating the "last modified" date?
  15. Can an account include multiple subsidiaries? How to filter by them in the API?
  16. Are any API methods planned for deprecation? What will replace them?
  17. Are some API endpoints available only with paid ERP modules or add-ons?
  18. Are some fields or features hidden unless specific ERP configuration settings are enabled?
  19. Does the ERP API return full relational data (e.g., linked documents, GL splits), or do we need extra queries?
  20. How can we detect deleted records if the API doesn‚Äôt expose a deleted flag or status?

These questions aren't just technical ‚Äî they help avoid costly mistakes, failed syncs, or misunderstood logic.

entry.title: Think Twice: Customizations That Break Your Integration
entry.content:
When you build data integrations between applications, small details are very important. If you miss them, you might need to rebuild parts of the integration later, which costs time and money.

One common case is when a team asks the client to make custom changes in their system to help sync the data. This might work in the short term, but it can also bring risks if you don‚Äôt think it through.

Before you suggest or require such changes, ask yourself:

  1. Will this work for all clients, or just a few?
  2. Does it require an extra license?
  3. Can the client do it themselves, or will they need outside help (for example, a vendor)?
  4. Is it supported in every version of the app?
  5. Could this setting be removed or changed later in the app?

Why this matters:

  1. Scalability ‚Äì> integrations should work for many clients, not only special cases.
  2. Maintainability ‚Äì> customizations can break after upgrades and create extra work.
  3. Risk reduction ‚Äì> planning early helps avoid broken syncs and unhappy clients.

By asking these questions up front, you can save a lot of rework and keep integrations stable in the long run.

entry.title: Stop Pulling Your Hair Out Over Integrations: Simple Tips
entry.content:
Using your app to integrate data from an ERP system requires some essential tips and things that you need to keep in mind to avoid problems later.

  1. Understand What Data You Need to Integrate
    Before setting up the integration, you should understand which ERP data your app will use and how it should be mapped inside your app. This helps prevent mistakes later.

  2. Choose the Right Integration Approach
    Your app can get data in different ways. Sometimes a simple API call is enough, sometimes you need more complex workflows to reduce the complexity and minimize API calls. Pick the approach that works for the data you need and the ERP system you‚Äôre integrating with.

  3. Make Sure the Data is Accurate
    Always check that the data coming from ERP is clean. Remove duplicates, verify references, and make sure everything matches your app‚Äôs requirements. Clean data makes the integration reliable.

  4. Think Carefully About Customizations
    ERP systems often need small tweaks to work perfectly with your app. But customizations can be risky, costly, and hard to maintain. Only ask clients for changes if it‚Äôs really necessary, and plan for long-term support.

  5. Plan for Scale and Maintenance
    Make sure your integration works for multiple clients and multiple ERP versions. Use automation in your app to handle repetitive tasks and make updates easier. This keeps everything stable as your client base grows.

  6. Consider Non-Functional Requirements
    It‚Äôs important to understand how much data the client plans to integrate and how often. This helps you estimate the system load, predict performance impact, and plan for stress testing. Thinking about this upfront prevents surprises and ensures the integration runs smoothly under real conditions.

entry.title: Organizational Changes in Accounting: Profit Center and Segment Reorganization
entry.content:
Are you already familiar with Organizational Changes in Accounting? What about profit center and segment reorganization?

Business Background

Organizational restructuring occurs when a company's business model changes due to internal or external factors. In these cases, restructuring is necessary and allows a company to adapt, survive, and ultimately grow.

In SAP S/4HANA, a company's organization is represented by reporting units, such as profit centers and/or segments.

What‚Äôs New?

As of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025, you can reorganize profit centers and segments for selected objects. During the reorganization process, profit centers and/or segments for these objects are reassigned and their stocks or balances are reposted to the new organizational entities.

In addition, some related apps for the Organizational Changes feature have been enhanced, new Customizing activities for segment reorganization are available, and new BAdIs are also available.

How can you use this feature?

First, ensure that you‚Äôve made all necessary configuration settings in Customizing. Then, you can use the related apps. For more information, refer to Configuration Activities for Organizational Changes.

The Manage Organizational Changes app is designed to assist you in the reorganization process. Here, you define an effective date in the future, on which the reassignment of profit centers to other objects occurs. You can use this app to control the overall organizational change process and, from here, you can navigate to related apps for organizational changes.

Furthermore, reporting is available after an organizational change has been simulated or processed, and after it has been completed. You can use the available reports to analyze the effect of a reorganization as well as the corresponding reassignment of profit centers and/or segments.

Further Information

For more information, about what‚Äôs new in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025, refer to What‚Äôs New for Organizational Changes in Accounting.

For more information about Organizational Changes in Accounting, including specific details related to profit center and segment reorganizations, refer to the following:

  • Organizational Changes in Accounting
  • Scope for Profit Center Reorganizations
  • Scope for Segment Reorganizations
  • Configuration Activities for Organizational Changes
  • Business Add-Ins for Organizational Changes
  • Apps and Programs for Organizational Changes

entry.title: Data quality comes at a price - also in in hospitals and clinics
entry.content:
Source: generated by Google Gemini

Initial situation

Data quality plays an essential role in virtually all core processes in hospitals and clinics, whether in medication, patient care, or supply logistics. In addition, data quality is not only an operational necessity, but also vital to compliance with regulations and laws (e.g., traceability of drugs or implants).

‚ÄúGarbage in = garbage out‚Äù

This makes it all the more important for every hospital or clinic to be aware of the importance of efficient data management.

In reality, however, there are many challenges in this area because the historically grown and often very heterogeneous system landscape with numerous clinical systems, ERP systems, and additional applications makes centralized and uniform data management difficult. In terms of data quality, it should be added that master data in particular must be maintained and distributed with a great deal of effort, often manually, which leads to the undesirable situation of poor-quality master data entering the clinical systems (‚Äúgarbage in‚Äù) and the resulting transaction data in the form of prescriptions, services, or consumption (‚Äúgarbage out‚Äù) being transferred from the systems to the ERP system.

This leads to numerous operational problems, whether in the supply logistics of medicines, medical products, and consumables for patients, suboptimal procurement of these operationally essential goods, or ultimately in rejections by health insurance companies due to incorrect service invoices.

Way out

Anyone who believes that the use of new technologies or new tools such as AI will solve the problems described above is likely to be bitterly disappointed. Instead, what is needed is the establishment of a centrally managed and organizationally strong data management system with the aim of creating a new awareness of a ‚Äúdata-centric‚Äù orientation within the organization.

What are the most important factors for successful data management to ensure data quality?

  1. Golden source: The principle is one ‚Äúgolden source‚Äù per data area or data object. Ideally, there is only one system (e.g., data warehouse, master data management) in the target architecture as the leading system or ‚Äúgolden source.‚Äù In practice, however, this is not always feasible due to the system landscape and its history and complexity, because the implementation does not justify the expected benefits due to the anticipated costs and implementation time. It is therefore much more important to mandatorily always define one leading system or one ‚Äúgolden source‚Äù per data area or data object.
  2. Validation: Data quality can be ensured most easily and efficiently at the source or during data generation. With suitable validation rules, necessary technical (e.g., pharmaceutical validation of drugs) and technical (e.g., duplicate checking) rules can be checked. This is the only way to prevent ‚Äúbad‚Äù data from entering the system in the first place.
  3. Automation: Unfortunately, manual data entry or data mutations of any kind are a frequent cause of operational inefficiencies, loss of data quality, and, last but not least, great frustration for data users. The maxim is therefore: as little manual intervention as possible in data transfer or data distribution, but maximum data automation via suitable interfaces, including monitoring and, if necessary, error messages (alerting).
  4. Quality assurance: In practice, actual quality assurance is often neglected because employees are often busy with manual or semi-automated data tasks and do not have the time for quality assurance. First, the data management challenges described above must be solved so that, in the next stage of data maturity, quality assurance with corresponding quality reports or KPIs can be achieved. However, once these control mechanisms for data quality have been implemented, quality problems can be identified much earlier (e.g., data records with missing batch information for implants) and more proactively (e.g., incorrect data records in service billing), and appropriate measures can be taken. Added to this are the possibilities offered by AI to apply increasingly intelligent control mechanisms.

Source: own illustration

Conclusion

Data quality is not a ‚Äúsure-fire success‚Äù and comes at a price. However, this is less about implementing new IT systems and IT tools and more about organizational awareness of the importance of professional data management. Otherwise, the old adage ‚Äúgarbage in = garbage out‚Äù will remain true, resulting in costly operational inefficiency and a lack of potential for more digitized and data-driven processes.

entry.title: Everything you need to get started with SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh
entry.content:
Introduction - Why Now Is the Moment to get started with Event-driven Architecture

As enterprises accelerate their journey to the cloud, business requirements are evolving at a rapid pace. SAP S/4HANA is increasingly being positioned as the digital core - designed to support greater agility, continuous transformation, and real-time responsiveness. In globally distributed organizations, the demand for instant data access and the need to decouple core systems from fast-moving innovations are defining a new dimension of how businesses operate.

Despite this shift, several integration challenges stand in the way of a seamless cloud transformation:

  • Traditional on-premise integration technologies are no longer sufficient to meet the speed, flexibility, and scalability required by today‚Äôs hybrid, cloud-based landscapes.
  • Modern integration approaches must be cloud-native and hybrid by design, capable of operating reliably across regionally distributed environments and ecosystems.
  • Real-time, event-based integration is becoming the emerging best practice, especially for high-volume, data-driven scenarios such as omnichannel commerce and intelligent supply chains.

SAP‚Äôs Answer?

SAP has developed a comprehensive response to these evolving needs by extending the SAP Integration Suite with modern, event-driven capabilities:

  • SAP Integration Suite provides powerful, cloud-ready tools and methodologies to enable integration across heterogeneous IT landscapes - on-premise, cloud, or hybrid.
  • Legacy on-premise integration architectures can be efficiently transformed into scalable, cloud-based models to meet today‚Äôs agility and performance requirements.
  • Event-driven integrations complement traditional methods by enabling real-time, loosely coupled interactions between systems - powering new business models and dynamic processes.

To support this, SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh offers a fully managed, enterprise-grade event streaming and management service which includes a robust set of features built for enterprise needs:

  • A distributed mesh of event brokers that can be deployed across any environment - public or private cloud, on-premise, or hybrid setups.
  • Elastic scalability, from small-scale projects to very large enterprise-grade use cases, without compromising performance or reliability.
  • Comprehensive support for event streaming, event management, and event monitoring, ensuring full visibility and control.
  • An advanced management toolset with features like message routing, filtering, deployment configuration, and distributed tracing to ensure seamless operations.

 

Complementing Traditional Integration Approaches

While event-driven architecture opens up new possibilities, it‚Äôs not a replacement - it‚Äôs a powerful complement. SAP Integration Suite continues to serve as a leading integration platform-as-a-service (iPaaS), enabling smooth integration of cloud and on-premise applications. Advanced Event Mesh enhances this by delivering a global, enterprise-grade event mesh, complete with the tools needed to operate and optimize it for maximum business value.

 

What is the value of Event-driven Architectures?

Today‚Äôs enterprise IT landscapes are often burdened by legacy integration patterns that are no longer fit for purpose. These outdated methods not only limit agility but also introduce complexity, latency, and inefficiencies across systems. Several common patterns highlight the limitations of traditional integration:

  • Batch Delivery introduces delays in transmitting information across systems.
  • Point-to-Point Connections result in a tangled web of integrations that are brittle and hard to scale.
  • Periodic Polling causes unnecessary system load and latency, constantly checking for updates.
  • Decentralized Data leaves critical information scattered and siloed across various domains.

With digital transformation accelerating and real-time responsiveness becoming essential, this traditional approach simply can‚Äôt keep up. Modern businesses need an integration model that is more flexible, scalable, and event-aware. This is where event-driven architecture comes into play. Rather than building rigid connections between applications, this model embraces asynchronous communication, where events trigger actions across a loosely coupled ecosystem. The advantages of this approach are clear:

  • Broadcasting: Events are published across a mesh; applications can subscribe to what‚Äôs relevant to them.
  • Decoupling: The publisher doesn't need to know who consumes the events, simplifying development and enabling flexible scaling.
  • Filtering: Subscribers only receive the information they‚Äôve explicitly asked for - nothing more, nothing less.

By shifting to an event-driven mindset, enterprises can significantly reduce integration complexity, respond to changes in real time, and create more resilient, adaptive system architectures.

Many organizations are held back by spaghetti architectures - a tangle of point-to-point integrations that are hard to manage and slow to adapt. These rigid systems make it difficult to innovate, scale, or respond quickly to change.

 

To break free, modern enterprises are adopting a publish-subscribe model powered by events and APIs. Instead of tightly coupled connections, applications communicate through a shared event mesh and standardized APIs - creating a modular, flexible integration layer.

This shift enables:

  • Faster rollout of new services
  • Real-time data flow across systems
  • Easier reuse and scaling of integration assets

By moving to an event- and API-driven architecture, you lay the foundation for scalable, agile digital transformation.

 

Resources for the Architect persona: The System Strategist

Event-driven architecture enables real-time visibility into business operations by mirroring key business moments as events (e.g., OrderPlaced, CustomerSignedUp). This empowers decision-makers to:

    • Respond faster to market and customer changes
    • Unlock real-time analytics and insights
    • Drive automation and efficiency across business processes
    • Build a digital foundation for future innovation (AI, ML, IoT)

 

Introductory Assets

Why do I need this asset?

Event-driven Architecture website on SAP.com

Whitepaper on a future-proof integration Strategy

Before diving deep into the technical details and implementation, take some time to familiarize yourself with event-driven architectures and how SAP can help you achieve them.

Resources for the Architect Persona: The System Strategist

EDA is the architectural pattern that solves critical challenges like tight coupling, brittle integrations, and slow change propagation. Architects adopt EDA to:

    • Decouple systems using asynchronous event flows
    • Build reactive, resilient, and scalable services
    • Align software design with real-world domain events
    • Support microservices and domain-driven design (DDD) practices

Event-driven integration reduces point-to-point complexity and makes systems more manageable. For technical teams, this means:

entry.title: CDP Connector Deleting Contacts in Emarsys?
entry.content:
Hi team,

When I set up the Connector for CDP to Emarsys without a Real Time Action but just normal "Create or Update" action, does that normal "Create or Update" action also delete contacts in Emarsys when they are deleted in CDP or is that only happening with the Real Time Action?

Thank you.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: CDP Connector Deleting Contacts in Emarsys?
entry.content:
The "Create or Update" action in the CDP Connector for Emarsys is primarily designed to create new contacts or update existing ones in Emarsys based on the data from the CDP. It does not inherently handle the deletion of contacts in Emarsys when they are deleted in the CDP. This behavior is typically exclusive to the Real Time Action, which can be configured to handle deletions or other specific actions based on real-time events. If you need to synchronize deletions, you would likely need to set up a separate process or use the Real Time Action to manage this behavior.

Documentation: Configuring the Create or Update a Contact -Automatic Activation Action

entry.title: Mehr als nur Technologie: Wie menschzentrierte KI Akzeptanz und Mehrwert schafft
entry.content:
Dieser Artikel erscheint demn√§chst leicht angepasst im Buch der Corporate Learning Community, Link darauf folgt. 

Als jemand, der sich seit vielen Jahren mit Lernen in Organisationen, Change Management und Technologietransformation besch√§ftigt, war f√ºr mich schnell klar: Die Einf√ºhrung generativer KI ist weit mehr als ein IT-Projekt. Es geht um Menschen, um Akzeptanz, um Wandel, um neue Formen des Lernens.

Ich bin schon lange Teil von Communities ‚Äì sei es durch den Austausch auf BarCamps, durch Gespr√§che im Podcast oder durch Formate wie dem CLC Promptathon 2024, den ich mit Begeisterung mit organisiert habe. Gerade dieser Promptathon war f√ºr mich ein Aha-Erlebnis: In einem hybriden Setting haben wir gemeinsam ausprobiert, wie uns generative KI konkret im Arbeitsalltag unterst√ºtzen kann. Es war ein echter Peer-Learning-Prozess ‚Äì offen, co-kreativ, experimentell mit einer sehr positiven Stimmung im Raum. Genau dieses erlebnisorientierte Lernen, halte ich f√ºr entscheidend, wenn wir von KI-Adoption sprechen. Denn KI versteht man nur, wenn man es nutzt.

Lernen entsteht durch Austausch, durch Reflexion, durch das gemeinsame Machen. Durch das gemeinsame Machen entsteht eine Energie, die nie in formellen Belehrungen durch Experten entsteht. Und das gilt auch besonders f√ºr KI. Nur wer selbst ausprobiert, wer mit anderen Erfahrungen teilt und gemeinsam L√∂sungen entwickelt, kann das volle Potenzial heben ‚Äì f√ºr sich pers√∂nlich und f√ºr die Organisation.

Diese Erfahrungen haben mich in meiner √úberzeugung best√§rkt, dass die menschzentrierte Gestaltung von KI-Initiativen kein ‚ÄûNice-to-have‚Äú ist, sondern ein zentraler Erfolgsfaktor. In diesem Artikel m√∂chte ich deshalb meine Perspektive auf die vier entscheidenden Faktoren f√ºr erfolgreiche KI-Adoption teilen ‚Äì mit einem besonderen Fokus auf den Menschen im Zentrum der Ver√§nderung. 

Die Herausforderung der generativen K√ºnstlichen Intelligenz 

Generative KI entwickelt sich mit einer krassen Geschwindigkeit und ver√§ndert die Art, wie wir arbeiten, lernen und kommunizieren. Doch w√§hrend Unternehmen immer mehr in KI-Technologie investieren, bleibt der erhoffte Produktivit√§tsschub oft aus. Viele reden auch davon, dass wir speziell in Deutschland einen KI-Kompetenz Gap haben. Und neben dieser Kompetenz-L√ºcke gibt es zudem die Pilot-Falle:  Unternehmen f√ºhren zwar oft erfolgreiche Einzelprojekte durch als Piloten, schaffen aber nicht den Sprung zur unternehmensweiten Skalierung.

Die Herausforderung liegt meines Erachtens nicht prim√§r in der Implementierung der Technologie, sondern in der Akzeptanz und effektiven Nutzung durch die Menschen in der Organisation.  

Unternehmen, die KI-Projekte rein technisch betrachten, scheitern h√§ufig an mangelnder Nutzung und Akzeptanz. Diese Nutzung und Akzeptanz wird auch Adoption benannt. Der Schl√ºssel dazu liegt meiner Ansicht nach in einem integrierten, menschenzentrierten Ansatz, der folgende vier Komponenten umfasst:

  1. Human-Centered Design Mindset & Practices
  2. Technical Support & Consulting
  3. Organizational Change Management
  4. Learning and Enablement (AI Upskilling)

Weiterbildung und Lernen wie es in der Corporate Learning Community praktiziert wird, ist hier einer der wesentlichen Elemente. Daneben ist eine fundierte Strategie notwendig mit klarer Zielsetzung und strukturiertem Vorgehen, Blick auf die technologische Plattform und Architektur, Nutzung hochwertiger Daten.  Je nach Kontext ist zudem die Ber√ºcksichtigung von Governance, Ethik und Regulierung ‚Äì auch ‚Äûverantwortungsvolle KI‚Äú genannt eminent wichtig.

Die vier Bereiche und Faktoren der AI Adoption

Im Artikel m√∂chte ich mich jedoch dem Thema Adoption, Nutzung & Akzeptanz widmen. Was machen diese vier Faktoren des integrierten, menschenzentrierten Ansatz aus?

 

Abb.1: Die vier Bereiche der AI Adoption

Komponente 1: Human-zentriertes Design - Mindset & Praktiken

Im Kontext von KI bedeutet dies, die Bed√ºrfnisse der Nutzenden in den Mittelpunkt zu stellen und von dort aus zu denken. F√ºr die Entwicklung einer KI-Strategie ist dabei entscheidend, aus der Vielzahl m√∂glicher Anwendungsf√§lle diejenigen zu identifizieren und zu priorisieren, die einen echten Mehrwert bieten. Bew√§hrte Design-Thinking-Kriterien bieten hierf√ºr einen strukturierten Rahmen:

  • Desirability: K√∂nnen konkrete Probleme durch KI gel√∂st werden wo auch Bedarf besteht?
  • Feasibility: Ist eine technische Umsetzung m√∂glich oder ist die Umsetzung nicht unn√∂tig komplex?
  • Viability: Kann das Unternehmen von der L√∂sung profitieren - gibt es einen Mehrwert?

F√ºr die Auswahl geeigneter KI-Szenarien haben sich Formate wie Business AI Exploration & Discovery Workshops oder Business AI Design Workshops bew√§hrt. Diese Methoden erm√∂glichen es, echte Nutzerbed√ºrfnisse interdisziplin√§r zu identifizieren und passende L√∂sungsans√§tze zu entwickeln.

Ob Design Thinking, Co-Creation, iteratives Prototyping, agiles Coaching oder andere Methoden ‚Äì entscheidend ist, dass die Nutzenden im Zentrum steht und L√∂sungen aus seiner Perspektive gedacht werden. Die Bearbeitung realer Probleme mit echten Nutzerdaten legt den Grundstein f√ºr die sp√§tere Akzeptanz und erfolgreiche Implementierung generativer KI. Neben der Nutzung von Wissen gibt es mehr Commitment und Motivation durch Einbindung ‚Äì sei es auch nur von Vertretern der Nutzer. Sehr n√ºtzlich ist hierbei der kostenfreie Methoden Toolkit des SAP Apphaus mit dedizierten KI Workshop Templates. 

Zur Humanzentrierung geh√∂rt f√ºr mich zudem auch der incl. Reflektion der ethischen Nutzung von KI - mehr dazu im verlinkten Podcast.  

Komponente 2: Technischer Support

Ich finde den Dreiklang nach der SAP KI Strategie sehr schl√ºssig:

  • Chatbots & conversational Interfaces ob SAP Joule, ChatGPT, Gemini oder Claude als Interface f√ºr die KI-gest√ºtzte Arbeit
  • In bestehende Software integrierte KI ‚Äì sei es der MS Co-Pilot bei Microsoft oder verschiedene eingebettete Use Cases in SAP Unternehmenssoftware wie z.B. bei SAP SuccessFactors oder SAP S/4HANA.
  • Das Entwickeln eigener Anwendungen und besonders Agenten zur Optimierung und Automatisierung von Arbeit oder ganz neuer Anwendungen.  

Neben der eigentlichen KI Software, sollte auch die KI Einf√ºhrung technisch unterst√ºtzt werden. Hilfreich dabei sind z.B. Tools f√ºr Prozessmanagement, -analyse und -mining, f√ºr Zusammenarbeit und Kommunikation wie Enterprise Social Networks mit Wikis, Foren etc., Digital Adoption Plattformen wie WalkMe zu Guidance,  Monitoring & Automatisierung der Nutzererfahrung sowie Tools f√ºr Umfragen zur Messung der qualitativen Akzeptanz. SAP fasst diese Digitalsierung von Software Einf√ºhrung und Betrieb auch unter dem Modell der Digital Toolchain zusammen.

Wichtig ist hier ein Punkt: Einf√ºhrung von KI sollte nicht (nur) mit alten Tools und Ans√§tzen gemacht werden wie Powerpoint, Excel oder E-Mail. Hier sollte man auch immer darauf achten, bessere Tools und Ans√§tze oder sogar KI selbst zu nutzen.   

Komponente 3: Organizational Change Management

Jenseits der individuellen Perspektive bedeutet KI-Adoption stets auch organisatorischer Wandel. Die Erfahrung zeigt: Selbst technisch exzellente KI-L√∂sungen scheitern, wenn der Ver√§nderungsprozess nicht systematisch gestaltet und begleitet wird. 

F√ºr erfolgreiche Ver√§nderungsprozesse sind verschiedene Faktoren relevant:

  1. Klarheit, Transparenz und Mehrwert: Die Vorteile der neuen Technologie m√ºssen f√ºr Organisationen, Teams und einzelne Rollen klar kommuniziert werden. Mitarbeitende m√ºssen verstehen, wie die Technologie ihre Arbeit effizienter und besser macht. Oft werden Vorteile nur High Level auf Management Ebene in Zahlen & high-level KPIs formuliert, was zu abstrakt ist und niemanden abholt.
  2. Vertrauen und Benutzerfreundlichkeit: Das Design aus Nutzerperspektive und der einfache Zugang der KI-Anwendungen sind entscheidend. Vertrauen in die Tools gewinnt zunehmend an Bedeutung. Besonders bei KI sind vertrauensf√∂rdernde Ma√ünahmen wie Transparenz der Modelle, Kl√§rung was mit individuellen Daten geschieht oder √úberpr√ºfung auf m√∂glichen Bias wichtig.
  3. Datengest√ºtzte Ver√§nderungsbegleitung: F√ºr eine erfolgreiche Transformation empfiehlt sich ein datengest√ºtzter Ansatz. Bew√§hrt haben sich f√ºnf Ver√§nderungsdimensionen aus Nutzersicht: Awareness, Acceptance, Enablement, Empowerment und Commitment. Durch regelm√§√üiges Pulsf√ºhlen dieser Dimensionen entlang der KI Einf√ºhrung kann der Fortschritt der KI-Adoption gemessen und bei Bedarf nachgesteuert werden. Bei SAP nennen wir das beispielsweise Deep-Transformation-Insights. Die technische Umsetzung davon erfolgt dabei mit Tools f√ºr Prozessanalyse und -modellierung sowie systematischen Befragungen. Dies erm√∂glicht ein pr√§zises Bild des Ver√§nderungsfortschritts und gezielte Ma√ünahmen bei Akzeptanzproblemen.

Komponente 4: Learning and Enablement   

Eine der gro√üen KI-Investitionen sind derzeit Umschulungen bzw. Weiterbildungen (auch gerne Upskilling genannt). Neben allgemeinem Verst√§ndnis und Kenntnissen verschiedener Tools wird oft die Kompetenz des Prompt Engineerings hervorgehoben. Ich w√ºrde das weiter fassen und es als Handling von KI Tools wie Chatbots im eigenen Arbeitskontext sehen - oft wird dies auch als AI Literacy bezeichnet.

Dar√ºber hinaus kann es hilfreich sein, fortgeschrittene Techniken zu erlernen im Prompten, das Entwickeln von Assistenten oder Agenten. Menschliche Sprache ersetzt Programmiersprache, und mit generativer KI wird Low- oder No-Code-Entwicklung Realit√§t. Letzteres wird auch gerne Vibe-Coding gennannt.

Neben dem Erlernen und Verst√§ndnis von Grundlagen geht es um den Einsatz generativer KI in der jeweiligen t√§glichen Arbeit. F√ºr wichtige Zielgruppen wie Softwareentwicklung, F&E, Kundenservice, Marketing oder IT werden oft spezielle interne Akademien eingerichtet.

F√ºr den SAP Kontext haben wir im Blog SAP AI Training und SAP AI Skills Self-Assessment relevante KI Lernangebote ausgew√§hlt.

Wie schon erw√§hnt versteht man KI vor allem, indem man es nutzt. Hierf√ºr eignen sich meiner Meinung nach besonders Ans√§tze aus dem Peer-Learning. M√∂gliche Methoden umfassen Workshops oder Hackathons, auch Promtathons genannt, Lernen in Gruppen, Communities oder Mentoring.

Jeder Job hat Aufgaben, bei denen generative KI helfen kann, wie die schnellere oder bessere Recherche, Inhaltserstellung einschlie√ülich Zusammenfassung oder √úbersetzung, Datenverarbeitung und -analyse, Softwareentwicklung und etliches mehr.

Eine M√∂glichkeit des Peer Learning ist das der Lerngruppen oder Lernzirkel. Das LernOS-Framework, ein Rahmenwerk f√ºr lebenslanges Lernen mit vielen openSource Lern-Leitf√§den beinhaltet beispielsweise einen KI-Lernleitfaden. Dieser Leitfaden strukturiert eine selbstgesteuerte Lernreise kleiner Gruppen mit fachlichem Input und √úbungen rund um generative KI. Dies erm√∂glicht das Lernen am Arbeitsplatz, einschlie√ülich der Analyse und Bearbeitung individueller Anwendungsf√§lle, und kann einfach und sogar relativ kostenneutral realisiert werden, beispielsweise im eigenen Team.

Eine schon erw√§hnte Lernform ist der Promtathon, der eine Art Hackathon ist, wobei kleine Gruppen Herausforderungen aus Ihrem Arbeitsalltag mit KI-Tool l√∂sen. Firmen wie die Deutsche Telekom, Continental oder auch SAP nutzen dieses Format bereits.

Bei der Gestaltung solcher praxisorientierten Lernformate sind aus eigener Erfahrung folgende Punkte zu beachten:

  • Nutzung zentraler Kommunikationstools, z.B. digitale Whiteboards
  • Analyse und Nutzung von Herausforderungen aus dem t√§glichen Arbeitsleben
  • Selbstorganisation f√∂rdern und fordern
  • Diversit√§t der Skills in den Lerngruppen
  • Minimaler Input, daf√ºr maximale Praxis 
  • Dokumentation und Reflexion der Ergebnisse und des L√∂sungswegs

Austausch in Communities wie der SAP Training und Change Community, der Corporate Learning Community oder der benachbarten LernOS Community ist f√ºr Learning Experten ein wichtiges Lern- und Experimentierfeld. Im besten Fall entstehen wie hier durch Co-Creation sogar Werkzeuge,  die der AI Adoption weiterhelfen.

Aufgrund der dynamischen Entwicklung im Bereich KI wird das kontinuierliche Lernen neuer KI Anwendungen und Modelle auch √ºber 2025 hinaus sehr relevant sein. Auch hier eigenen sich Methoden aus dem Peer-Learning und dem erfahrungsbasierten Lernen.

Adoption reicht nicht, es ben√∂tigt auch Adaption & Transformation

Neben den 4 Dimensionen ist der Unterschied zwischen Adoption, Adaption & Transformation zentral.

Adoption bedeutet die Akzeptanz und eigentliche Nutzung neuer KI-Technologien. Jedoch sollte man nicht nur bestehende Aufgaben schneller mit KI machen.

Adaption geht dar√ºber hinaus: Arbeitsweisen, Aufgaben und Prozesse werden aktiv an die Technologie angepasst. Dies verlangt Ver√§nderungsbereitschaft, Lernen und Experimentieren, um KI sinnvoll zu integrieren.   

Transformation schlie√ülich beschreibt den tiefgreifenden Wandel von Aufgaben, aber auch Gesch√§ftsmodellen, Wertsch√∂pfung und Rollen. KI erm√∂glicht Neues, zuvor nicht dagewesenes und ver√§ndert damit Arbeit, Organisation und Zusammenarbeit.

Abb. 2: Das Adoption, Adaption, Transformation Modell (eigene Darstellung)

Diese 3 Stufen sind zentrale Schritte eines Entwicklungsprozesses. Auf keinen Fall darf man auf der Stufe der reinen Nutzung stehen bleiben, will man das Potential von KI wirklich nutzen. √Ñhnlich sieht dies auch Josh Bersin (2025) in seinem Beitrag ‚Äûdie vier Stufen der KI Transformation‚Äú. Passend dazu fordert Ethan Mollicks (2025) Konzept ‚ÄûLeadership, Lab and Crowd‚Äú f√ºr erfolgreiche KI-Transformation, den Gap zwischen Theorie und Praxis durch organisationale Lernprozesse zu √ºberwinden.

Reflektion zur menschzentrierten KI Adoption

F√ºr die Einf√ºhrung und Nutzung generativer KI ist es wichtig, dass jeder aktiv experimentiert und versucht, KI √ºberall dort einzusetzen, wo es m√∂glich ist. Wie beim Lernen vom Autofahren kann man etwas dar√ºber lesen ‚Äì aber um es wirklich zu beherrschen und sich auch anzupassen, muss man es erleben und √ºben.

Organisationen m√ºssen daher nicht nur die Werkzeuge, sondern auch Raum zum Lernen und Experimentieren anbieten. Hier k√∂nnen Communities und Peer-Learning helfen. 

Neben dem Toolset ist es zudem hilfreich, Menschen f√ºr die KI-Nutzung zu belohnen und nicht zu bestrafen. Wenn Produktivit√§tsgewinne erzielt werden, m√ºssen auch die Mitarbeiter davon profitieren bzw. sollten keine Angst vor den Folgen haben. Psychologische Sicherheit ist dabei der Schl√ºssel zur Bereitschaft, Innovationen zu teilen oder sich √ºberhaupt zu trauen, etwas neues zu versuchen. Daher ist es hilfreich, eine solche Kultur der psychologischen Sicherheit zu f√∂rdern, einschlie√ülich des Lernens aus Fehlern und des Vorlebens durch Beispiel. (Ja - Manager reden oft noch zuviel √ºber KI, anstatt KI selbst auch aktiv zu nutzen). 

Ohne den Fokus auf Menschen werden KI-Implementierungen nicht nur weniger erfolgreich sein - sie k√∂nnen sogar sch√§dlich sein. Verhindern wir dies und arbeiten wir gemeinsam an einem menschenzentrierten Einsatz von KI. 

Quellen

Bersin, Josh (2025): The Road To AI-Driven Productivity: Four Stages of Transformation. Abgerufen am 03.09.2025 unter https://joshbersin.com/2024/11/how-to-make-productivity-soar-four-stages-of-ai-transformation/

CLC Promptathon: Blogs & Podcast (2024) + Leitfaden f√ºr Promptathons

Jenewein, Thomas (2025): AI Adoption: from technology to successful usage, acceptance to adaption and transformation. SAP Blogs. Abgerufen am 03.09.2025 unter https://community.sap.com/t5/sap-training-and-change-management/ai-adoption-from-technology-to-successful-usage-acceptance-to-adaption-and/ba-p/13922954

Jenewein, Thomas (2024): Generative K√ºnstliche Intelligenz im Corporate Learning: Use Cases, Beispiele und Tips. Abgerufen am 03.09.2025 unter https://community.sap.com/t5/sap-training-and-change-management/generative-k%C3%BCnstliche-intelligenz-im-corporate-learning-use-cases-beispiele/ba-p/13767754

Im EducationNewscast Podcast reflektiere ich zudem regelm√§√üig Themen rund um KI ‚Äì neben konkreten Projekterfahrungen stammen hier auch einige meiner Erkenntnisse hier im Blog

LernOS KI Leitfaden (2025) Leitfaden zum Erlernen generativer KI in Lernzirkeln

Mollick, Ethan (2025): Making AI Work: Leadership, Lab, and Crowd. A formula for AI in companies. Abgerufen am 03.09.2025 unter https://www.oneusefulthing.org/p/making-ai-work-leadership-lab-and

Mollick, Ethan (2024): Co-Intelligence: Living and Working with AI. Penguin Random House UK.

Verbindet Euch gerne auch via Linkedln I Mastodon I Bluesky I Podcast

entry.title: Observability for non-SAP Components using SAP Cloud ALM
entry.content:
• Introduction
  • Architecture Overview
  • Configuration Overview
  • Instrument Tomcat with OpenTelemetry
  • Register Service in SAP Cloud ALM
  • Get SAP Cloud ALM API Service Credentials
  • Install and configure the OTel Collector
  • Activate Data Collection in SAP Cloud ALM
  • Check results in Health Monitoring
  • Activate and check results in Real User Monitoring
  • Activate and check results in Integration and Exception Monitoring
  • Key Takeaways
  • Link Collection
  • Glossary

 

Introduction

In today's enterprise environments, organizations increasingly depend on a diverse mix of tools, platforms, and custom applications, both SAP and non-SAP. SAP's core strategic goal is to empower IT teams by simplifying this complexity and seamlessly integrating and monitoring these varied systems and services.

If you‚Äôre running non-SAP workloads‚Äîlike Java applications on Apache Tomcat‚Äîbut want centralized visibility and operations in SAP Cloud ALM, OpenTelemetry provides a clean path. SAP Cloud ALM can be used as a centralized, unified platform for monitoring, managing, and optimizing all components, including cloud-native services and third-party systems.

In this blog, we'll explore how you can leverage SAP Cloud ALM to monitor non-SAP systems using Inbound raw APIs and OpenTelemetry. As part of this blog we will focus on Health Monitoring, Real User monitoring and Integration and Exception monitoring. More applications can consume external signals, complete list per signal type can be found in link collection at the end.

 

Architecture Overview

The list of key components for monitoring external entities with SAP Cloud ALM using OpenTelemetry includes:

  • OpenTelemetry Java Agent
  • OpenTelemetry Collector
  • SAP Cloud ALM raw inbound APIs

The OpenTelemetry Java Agent is a tool designed to automatically collect telemetry data, such as traces and metrics, from Java applications. It is part of the OpenTelemetry project, which aims to provide a standardized way to gather observability data for applications, making it easier to monitor their performance and troubleshoot issues.

The OpenTelemetry Collector is a component of the OpenTelemetry project that serves as an intermediary for processing, transforming, and exporting telemetry data (traces, metrics, logs) to monitoring and observability backends.

SAP Cloud ALM raw inbound APIs are interfaces that allow external systems and applications to send telemetry data directly into SAP Cloud ALM applications like Health Monitoring, Real User Monitoring or Integration and Exception Monitoring.

In this article we will describe how to configure an external system (Tomcat server) to show metrics, logs and traces in SAP Cloud ALM using all the key components.

The receiving entity in our architecture is a SAP Cloud ALM application depending on the type of signal involved:

  • Real User Monitoring or Synthetic User Monitoring for traces
  • Health Monitoring for metrics
  • Exception Monitoring for logs

 

Configuration Overview

Required configuration steps can be summarized as follows:

  1. Instrument Tomcat with OpenTelemetry
  2. Register Service in SAP Cloud ALM
  3. Get SAP Cloud ALM API Service Credentials
  4. Install and configure the OTel Collector
  5. Activate Data Collection in SAP Cloud ALM

 

Instrument Tomcat with OpenTelemetry

In general, instrumenting an application or service with OpenTelemetry means adding the ‚Äúsensors‚Äù that let you see what the software is doing in production.

Instrumenting a Tomcat server with OpenTelemetry means enabling Tomcat and the web apps it hosts to emit standardized traces, metrics, and logs so you can see request flow, latency, errors, and resource usage.

This is exactly the role of the OpenTelemetry Java Agent which hooks into the JVM at startup and automatically detects common frameworks (JDBC, messaging, etc.) creating spans and metrics with appropriate context propagation. The agent can be setup to send data to a specific backend (like the OTel Collector) via configured exporters. Instrumentation is enabled/controlled by configuration (environment variables, system properties) rather than code.

The opentelemetry-javaagent.jar file must be placed in a directory accessible by the Tomcat server (e.g. $CATALINA_HOME/lib/) and the -javaagent:$CATALINA_HOME/lib/opentelemetry-javaagent.jar option must be added either to CATALINA_OPTS or the setenv.sh file like here:

#https://github.com/open-telemetry/opentelemetry-java-instrumentation/releases
#Previous: 1.33.3
#Current: 2.12.0
#attaches the OpenTelemetry Java agent to Tomcat at startup and turns on Tomcat-specific JMX metric scraping
export CATALINA_OPTS="$CATALINA_OPTS -javaagent:$CATALINA_HOME/lib/opentelemetry-javaagent_2.12.0.jar -Dotel.jmx.target.system=tomcat"

#uses OTLP over gRPC (port 4317) for exporting, more efficient if signals are sent to a Collector
export OTEL_EXPORTER_OTLP_PROTOCOL=grpc
#points all OTLP exports to the OpenTelemetry Collector (or backend) at host demo_otel, port 4317.
export OTEL_EXPORTER_OTLP_ENDPOINT=http://demo_otel:4317

#enable exporting logs, metrics and traces via OTLP
export OTEL_LOGS_EXPORTER=otlp
export OTEL_METRICS_EXPORTER=otlp
export OTEL_TRACES_EXPORTER=otlp

#sets resource attributes added to every signal: service name is Tomcat-Server and a custom tag sap.custom=ALM-Demo.
export OTEL_RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTES=service.name=Tomcat-Server,sap.custom=ALM-Demo

OTEL_EXPORTER_OTLP_PROTOCOL and OTEL_EXPORTER_OTLP_ENDPOINT are used to point where all the telemetry should go while OTEL_*EXPORTER options are used to make sure every signal gets shipped with the proper protocol (on modern agents, traces and metrics default to OTLP anyway, but explicitly enabling logs ensures they‚Äôre exported too if log correlation is configured).

OTEL_RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTES is just used to add some identity to the data by adding tags to every trace/metric/log with a service name and a custom attribute.

After restart, servlets, filters, and JSPs, as well as common libraries, will be auto-instrumented, and the server will start sending signals to the OTel host with no code modifications.

 

Register Service in SAP Cloud ALM

To configure non-SAP services, you need to ensure they can send signals to SAP Cloud ALM and that they are represented in the Landscape Management application in SAP Cloud ALM as an unspecific cloud service.

This is a crucial step because the Landscape ID  generated at the end of the process (e684466f-446d-4a53-a899-f0af6d94731e in this example) will be used in the OTel Collector configuration to send the signals to the proper entity in each application.

 

 

Get SAP Cloud ALM API Service Credentials

Any entity sending data to SAP Cloud ALM must be authenticated to be able consume the APIs. The procedure to enable SAP Cloud ALM APIs is described here. The goal is to be able to retrieve service credentials.

In this example service credentials are necessary to authenticate the collector with SAP Cloud ALM API, specifically clientid, clientsecret, and url attributes in the uaa section of the credentials form. This can be retrieved from the BTP Cockpit for the SAP Cloud ALM API service.

 

Install and configure the OTel Collector

As explained before, the OpenTelemetry collector is a proxy that can receive, process, and export telemetry data in various formats (such as Jaeger, Prometheus, and OTLP) and send it to one or more backends, including SAP Cloud ALM.

Collectors can be installed and setup in few minutes; there are essentially two options: use the image and binaries from the github release project (this option will include all the receivers, exporters and extensions) or build and install a custom collector configured using specific receivers, exporters and extensions. The minimal requirement needed to authenticate the collector to the SAP Cloud ALM API is the oauth2clientauthextension. 

Regardless the installation option, setup is done via a configuration file (otel-config.yaml in the example below). 

Using docker, it is quite straightforward to start and test a collector:

docker run -v ./otel-config.yaml:/etc/otelcol-contrib/config.yaml \
-p 127.0.0.1:4317:4317 \
-p 127.0.0.1:55679:55679  \
otel/opentelemetry-collector-contrib

This command runs the OpenTelemetry Collector in a Docker container, using a custom configuration file in the current directory (otel-config.yaml) and exposing two ports (4317 and 55679) for communication with the host.

The collector yaml file includes mainly four sections:

  • Receivers
  • Processors
  • Exporters
  • Services

Below is an example of a configuration file using the service credential attributes‚Äîspecifically clientid, clientsecret, and url‚Äîas explained in the "Get SAP Cloud ALM API Service Credentials" section. These attributes are used for oauth2client authentication within the OpenTelemetry Collector configuration.
When configuring the oauth2client extension, ensure that the token_url parameter is constructed by appending /oauth/token to the provided url value. This step is required for proper authentication against the SAP Cloud ALM API.

 

extensions:

#This enables zPages, a web-based UI for viewing in-process telemetry data.
#It listens on port 55679 and can be accessed via http://<otel-collector-host>:55679/zpages
  zpages:
    endpoint: 0.0.0.0:55679

#This is used to authenticate requests sent by the exporters. 
#In this case the client_id (sb-sapcloudalmapi!b48494|sapcloudalm!b36409) includes a character | which is not supported in the file or string.
#OpenTelemetry typically expects the client_id and client_secret to be provided via a file (e.g., client_id_file) or as a simple string without special characters like |, hence we use files here. 
#Make sure the files are protected and not accessible by unauthorized users.
 
  oauth2client/prod:
    client_id_file: ./client_id_file
    client_secret_file: ./client_secret_file
    token_url: https://calm-acme-demo.authentication.eu10.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token

#This defines a receiver that listens for telemetry data (metrics, logs, traces) from the otlp/tomcat source.
#It uses the gRPC protocol and listens on port 4317 for incoming data. This is the same port that the Tomcat OpenTelemetry Java agent is configured to send data to.
#Make sure that the port 4317 is open and not blocked by any firewall or network security group.
receivers:
  otlp/tomcat:
    protocols:
      grpc:
        endpoint: 0.0.0.0:4317

#This improves performance by reducing the number of requests and optimizing network usage.
processors:
  batch:

#These define exporters that send telemetry data to external systems.
#There are three exporters, one for each type of telemetry data: metrics, logs, and traces.
#Each exporter is configured to send data to a specific endpoint in the SAP Cloud ALM system
#Each exporter uses the oauth2client/prod extension for authentication.
exporters:
  otlphttp/tomcat_metrics:
    metrics_endpoint: https://eu10.alm.cloud.sap/api/calm-metrics/v1/metrics?serviceId=e684466f-446d-4a53-a899-f0af6d94731e&useCase=hm&dev=false&tag=otelcol_prodemo
    compression: none
    auth:
      authenticator: oauth2client/prod
    headers:
      Content-type: "application/x-protobuf"

  otlphttp/tomcat_logs:
    logs_endpoint: https://eu10.alm.cloud.sap/api/calm-logs/v1/logs?serviceId=e684466f-446d-4a53-a899-f0af6d94731e&useCase=exm&dev=false&tag=otelcol_prodemo
    compression: none
    auth:
      authenticator: oauth2client/prod
    headers:
      Content-type: "application/x-protobuf"

  otlphttp/tomcat_traces:
    traces_endpoint: https://eu10.alm.cloud.sap/api/calm-traces/v1/traces?serviceId=e684466f-446d-4a53-a899-f0af6d94731e&useCase=rum&dev=false&tag=otelcol_prodemo
    compression: none
    auth:
      authenticator: oauth2client/prod
    headers:
      Content-type: "application/x-protobuf"

#The service section ties everything together.
service:

#Uses the oauth2client/prod extension for authentication and enables zPages for monitoring.
  extensions: [zpages,oauth2client/prod]

#Defines how telemetry data flows:
  pipelines:
#Receives metrics, batches them, and sends them to otlphttp/tomcat_metrics.
    metrics/tomcat:
      receivers: [otlp/tomcat]
      processors: [batch]
      exporters: [otlphttp/tomcat_metrics]
#Receives logs, batches them, and sends them to otlphttp/tomcat_logs.
    logs/tomcat:
      receivers: [otlp/tomcat]
      processors: [batch]
      exporters: [otlphttp/tomcat_logs]
#Receives traces, batches them, and sends them to otlphttp/tomcat_traces.
    traces/tomcat:
      receivers: [otlp/tomcat]
      processors: [batch]
      exporters: [otlphttp/tomcat_traces]
Spoiler
You can check the status of the local collector accessing the link http://localhost:55679/debug/servicez. This will show you the enabled extensions and features. 

In short: 

  • Receiver otlp/tomcat collect telemetry data.
  • Processors (like batch) optimize the data before exporting.
  • Exporters, like otlphttp/tomcat_metrics, send the data to external systems (SAP Cloud ALM Health monitoring application)
  • Service defines how everything works together using pipelines like metrics/tomcat.

 

Collector metric data flow

 

Activate Data Collection in SAP Cloud ALM

After restarting the collector, signals will be sent to the SAP Cloud ALM applications. To actually see the data in each application, few additional steps are needed.

 

Check results in Health Monitoring

If everything is set up properly, Health Monitoring will display the metrics list for the custom Tomcat service you created. Simply choose "Unspecific Cloud Service" as the service type in the scope selector

Scope Selector for Unspecific Cloud Services

and confirm that data collection is enabled for the "Tomcat" service in your configuration.

 

Health Monitoring Overview and Service activation

 

To view system details, just click on the Unspecific Cloud Service tile:

 

Monitoring Overview

 

Monitoring System Details

 

Activate and check results in Real User Monitoring

To enable Real User Monitoring for Tomcat, select the unspecific cloud service

 

Real User Monitoring scope selection for Unspecific Cloud Services

 

click the configuration wheel, and activate data collection in Managed Components.

 

Real User Monitoring: Tomcat data collection and Overview

 

Requests traces will then be available in the detailed pages:

       RUM Requests Overview

 

RUM Request Executions

 

Activate and check results in Integration and Exception Monitoring

Error logs will appear on the Exception Monitoring page as soon as data collection is activated, just like Health Monitoring and Real User Monitoring.

 

Integration and Exception Monitoring Overview

  Integration and Exception Monitoring details

 

 

Key Takeaways

  • Unified Monitoring: SAP Cloud ALM enables centralised monitoring and management of both SAP and non-SAP systems, providing a centralized entry point for IT operations.
  • OpenTelemetry Integration: Leveraging the OpenTelemetry Java Agent and Collector allows for seamless collection and forwarding of telemetry data (metrics, logs, traces) from external systems such as Tomcat servers.
  • API-Driven Data Ingestion: SAP Cloud ALM‚Äôs raw inbound APIs facilitate direct ingestion of external telemetry data, supporting use cases like Health Monitoring, Real User Monitoring, Exception Monitoring and more.
  • Step-by-Step Configuration: The integration process involves instrumenting the external system, registering it in SAP Cloud ALM, obtaining API credentials, configuring the OpenTelemetry Collector, and activating data collection in the relevant SAP Cloud ALM applications.
  • Security and Authentication: Secure authentication is achieved using service credentials (client ID, client secret, and token URL) when configuring the OpenTelemetry Collector to communicate with SAP Cloud ALM.
  • Operational Visibility: Once configured, IT teams gain real-time visibility into the health, performance, and exceptions of external systems, enhancing proactive management and troubleshooting.
  • Extensibility: The approach is adaptable to a wide range of non-SAP workloads and can be extended to additional applications and signal types as needed.

 

Link Collection

  • RAW inbound APIs
  • Expert Portal
    • Health Monitoring
    • Real User Monitoring
    • Integration and Exception Monitoring 
  • OpenTelemetry
    • Java Agent
    • Java Agent Releases 
    • Collector
    • Custom Collector
    • Collector Contrib Release
    • Collector Oauth Extension

 

Glossary

BTP Cockpit (SAP Business Technology Platform Cockpit): is the web console for administering SAP BTP: manage accounts and regions, assign entitlements, provision services, configure environments and connectivity, handle users/roles and security, and monitor usage and billing.

OTel (OpenTelemetry): open-source observability framework that standardizes collection of telemetry data - traces, metrics, and logs- from applications and services, providing vendor-neutral SDKs, APIs, and agents to export data to backends for monitoring and analysis.

JMX (Java Management Extensions): Java technology for monitoring and managing applications, JVMs, and resources via MBeans, enabling runtime configuration, metrics, and operations through standard APIs and remote connectors (e.g., JMX RMI).

entry.title: Error V/005 ‚Äì Payment card duplication issue during customer extension to sales area
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

I‚Äôm working on a client requirement where a single payment card (credit card) number can be assigned to multiple customers.

To suppress the duplicate check error ‚Äî ‚ÄúPayment card is already used by other BP‚Äù ‚Äî we deactivated the implementation CVI_CC_CHECK_BP_SIDE from the BAdI BUPA_PCARD_CHECK. After deactivating it, the duplicate card error no longer appears.

However, we are now encountering a new error when extending a customer to a sales area and saving it:

Error: ‚ÄúCustomer data were not saved due to error V/005‚Äù
Long Text: ‚ÄúPayment card XXXXXXXX is already assigned (V/005)‚Äù

Could you please share your thoughts on how we can suppress these errors from the BP/Customer side while allowing multiple customers to use the same payment card?

Thank you,

Gaurav Mishra

entry.title: Re: How to migrate service purchase order data by migrati...
entry.content:
Hello @Lily16 

I believe I Provided the answer you mentioned below. Here is a follow up.

In summary, what you are trying to do is not supported in public cloud. The standard migration object does not support Purchase Orders that reference a Service Order. The migration template as you noticed contains Sales Order, Sales Item and so on, but does not include the Service Document and Service Document item fields. The reason is the clean-core approach used in the public cloud. Service-related Purchase Orders must be created automatically from Service Orders and not migrated or created manually.

What is recommended is for you, is to use scope item 4HH-Service Order Processing with External Procurement. Create the Service Order in the Manage Service Orders App. The system automatically generates a Purchase Requisition and then a Purchase Order linked to the Service Document.

If your legacy Pos are only needed for reporting (a workable fallback), you may load them through Migrate Purchase Orders but leave Service Order reference blank. These Pos will not be functionally linked to Service Orders.

The following references will provide you with more details.

Migration of Purchase Orders, https://api.sap.com/api/API_MATERIAL_DOCUMENT_SRV/overview

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_BUSINESS_BYDESIGN/0635ec3491974ad988be05d6b1dcf734/2da5a553722d1014a062d17a4124c536.html?locale=en-US

Blog: Migration Cockpit- Open Purchase Order confirms, the information you received is right. Here are some more details.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

PS: Did you contact your system administrator to activate the service order app?

Best regards

Chris
